results.title: Le Pactole = the Loot
results.brief_description:
A young couple pulls off a bank robbery only to be blackmailed by a witness, who turns out to be a corrupt police officer.

Credits: Producer, Roger Fleytoux ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Patrick Granier, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; photography, Edmond Richard ; music, Roger Loubet.
Cast: Richard Bohringer, Patrick Sebastien, Pauline Lafont, Marie Laforet, Bernadette Lafont.

results.title: Les Portes de la Nuit = Gates of the Night
results.creator_credit: Marcel Carne, Pierre Laurent and Raymond Borderie
results.brief_description:
Paris during the winter after the Liberation. Diego meets up with his friend Raymond Lecuyer. A tramp pretending to be Destiny predicts Diego will meet the most beautiful girl in the world. The same evening, Diego meets Malou. Malou is the daughter of a businessman who does not disguise his sympathy for the now defunct Vichy regime. Diego soon discovers that Malou’s brother, Guy, was the one who denounced Raymond to the Gestapo. Carne and Prevert paint a realistic portrait of the social landscape of France immediately after the Liberation, with its war victims, resistants, black-marketeers and Vichy nostalgics. For ‘Les portes de la nuit’ Alexandre Trauner re-created in studio the metro station Barbes-Rochechouart and several facades of houses along the canal St Martin.

Credits: Producers, Raymond Borderie, Pierre Laurent ; director, Marcel Carne ; writer, Jacques Prevert ; photography, Philippe Agostini ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; stills photographer, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Pierre Brasseur, Serge Reggiani, Yves Montand, Nathalie Nattier, Saturnin Fabre, Raymond Bussieres, Jean Vilar, Sylvia Bataille, Jane Marken, Dany Robin, Fabien Loris, Mady Berry, Julien Carette.

results.title: L'argent = Money
results.creator_credit: Robert Bresson, Jean-Pierre Baste and Patricia Moraz
results.brief_description:
A single forged banknote changes hands as a schoolboy prank and follows a remorseless path (the chain reaction of Tolstoy’s novella) which culminates in murder. Bresson ignores sociological and psychological explanation in austerely charting the paradoxical path of crime and punishment which leads the murderer towards redemption. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Jean-Pierre Baste, Patricia Moraz ; director, writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Emmanuel Manchuel, Pasqualino de Santis ; music, Jean-Sebastien Bach ; editor, Jean-Francois Naudon.
Cast: Christian Patey, Caroline Lang, Silvie van den Elsen, Vincent Risterucci.

results.title: Les Dames du Bois de Boulogne
results.brief_description:
Bresson’s second film, released in 1945 and scripted by Jean Cocteau. Made during the last days of the Occupation, the film combines the superficial glamour of the Parisian high society with the seething passions and jealousies that cause a spurned femme fatale, Helene, to seek her ex-lover’s humiliation. Through the climactic revelation of Helene’s deception, Bresson stages the deeper realisation of love’s redemptive power in an ending of truly magical transcendence. A landmark in cinema history… . Its influence on subsequent French cinema is far from exhausted” (David Thomson). The importance of ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ cannot be understated. Richard Roud, citing its formative influence on Antonioni, Demy, and Straub, among others, calls it ‘a universally seminal film.’ (In a recent interview, Godard provocatively called ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ the ‘only’ film of the French Resistance’, and Antonioni recently singled it out as a great influence on his own work.) Cocteau wrote the dialogue for this glistening melodrama of revenge, and though Bresson’s emerging style and his characteristic emphasis on entrapment, sacrifice, suffering and redemption are unmistakable, the world of ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ is also Cocteau’s, with its elegantly acid language, luxe setting, and Maria Casares’ piercing performance as a woman who arranges a bad marriage for the man who spurned her. Winner of the Louis Delluc prize for the most important French film of the year, ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ works perfectly as a razor-sharp conte cruel (Tom Milne). Reference: James Quandt. The poetry of precision: the films of Robert Bresson. Cinematheque Ontario. Online. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/bresson.htm. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Raoul ploquin ; director, writer, Robert Bresson ; dialogue, Jean Cocteau ; photography, Phillipe Agostini ; music, Jean-Jacques Grunenwald ; decors, Max Douy.
Cast: Maria Casares, Elina Labourdette, Lucienne Bogaert, Paul Bernard, Jane Marchat.

results.title: Le Petit Soldat = the Little Soldier
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
In Geneva, at the time of the Algerian War, a French secret agent, on a mission to kill a top man in the FLN, finds himself used as a pawn by both sides. Filmed in 1960, Godard’s second feature film was banned by the French government and released, with minor cuts, in 1963 because of its ambivalent attitude to the Algerian War and its reflection of brutality on both sides. Other reasons might have been its matter of fact filming of torture and the treatment of the political crisis as a confusing gangster movie.

Credits: Producer, Georges de beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Maurice Le Roux.
Cast: Michel Subor, Anna Karina, Henri-Jacques Huet, Laszlo Szabo, Mohamed Messoussa.

results.title: Adieu L'ami = So Long, Friend
results.brief_description:
A friendship develops between a French doctor and an American mercenary when both are discharged from the army. Dino and Propp combine forces to help a woman return some stolen bonds before the crime can be discovered. They become trapped for three days in the underground vault system. Propp helps Dino escape before he is captured by the police. The two fall victim to the woman who was used as bait to get them to open the safe. Note: In this version, Charles Bronson’s voice is dubbed in French by American filmmaker John Berry.

Credits: Producer, Serge Silberman ; director, Jean Herman ; writer, Sebastien Japrisot ; photography ; Jean-Jacques Tarbes ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Alain Delon, Charles Bronson, Olga Georges-Picot, Bernard Fresson, Brigitte Fossey.

results.title: Ballade Pour Un Chien = Ballad for a Dog
results.brief_description:
Remy Viachet is a lonely old man with money worries. During one of his solitary walks, he finds a stray dog and decides to adopt him. Remy manages to sneak the dog in his appartment unbeknown to the concierge. One day the old man is found dead in his flat, the floor littered with dog food tins intended for an animal that does not seem to exist.

Credits: Director, Gerard Vergez ; writers, Maurice Curry, Gerard Vergez ; photography, Patrice Pouget ; music, Francois Rabbath.
Cast: Charles Vanel, Julien Guiomar, Claude Genia, Colette Regis, Alfred Lenglet.

results.title: Agatha et les Lectures Illimitees
results.brief_description:
In a sprawling sea-side mansion, Agatha dialogues with her adored brother. Their impossible love, their common past come back to life as the conversation unfolds. Further viewing: ‘Duras filme’, an account of the making of ‘Agatha …’ - French Embassy Video Collection.

Credits: Director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Dominique Le Rigoleur ; music, Johannes Brahms.
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Yann Andrea, Margerite Duras [voice only].

results.title: The James Dean story: a different kind of motion picture
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, George W. George and Hughes Leisure Group
results.brief_description: This is a special documentary movie on the life of one of Hollywood’s greatest legends - as told by his relatives, friends and fellow actors. The presence of James Dean in this film has been made possible by the use of existing motion picture material, tape recordings of his voice and by means of dynamic exploration of still photographs.

results.title: L'aigle a Deux Tetes = the Two-Headed Eagle
results.creator_credit: Jean Cocteau, Alexandre Mnouchkine and Georges Dancigers
results.brief_description:
In a small mid-European kingdom in the 19th century, a young anarchist who happens to be the perfect look-alike of the dead king, breaks into the palace in order to kill the queen, but falls in love with her. Pauline Kael has characterized Jean Cocteau’s ‘The Two-Headed Eagle’ as an inversion of Cocteau’s ‘Beauty and the Beast’. On surface, this is true: In ‘Beauty’, the heroine awakens the handsome, good man lurking within the beast, while in ‘Eagle’ it is the woman who is aroused from her spell by the hero. Although Cocteau’s cinematic sense is too great to make the film look stagey, the screenplay smacks too much of the theatre. It is the most minor of his own directed films. ‘Il Mistero di Oberwald’ (The Mystery of Oberwald) directed by Michelangelo Antonioni was based on ‘The Two Headed Eagle’.

Credits: Producer, Georges Dancigers, Alexandre Mnouchkine ; director, Jean Cocteau ; writer, Jean Cocteau ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Christian Berard, Georges Wakhevitch ; stills photographer, Raymond Voin
Cast: Edwige Feuillere, Jean Marais, Jean Debucourt, Jacques Varennes, Silvia Monfort, Yvonne de Bray.
